ORDER
______________________________________________________________
On appeal from:
North West High Court, Mmabatho
(Lever AJ sitting as
court of first instance):
1 The order by the court a quo is set aside and the
following order substituted:
'(a) The matter is referred to trial.
(b) The notice of motion shall stand as a simple
summons.
(c) The applicant is ordered to deliver his declaration
within 21 days from the date of this order (provided that the days
between
16 December and 15 January, both inclusive, shall not be
counted as part of this period).
(d) The second respondent, the executors, are ordered to
deliver their plea within 21 days of the date of delivery of the
applicant's
declaration (subject to the same proviso contained in
(c), should the declaration be delivered before or during the period
specified
in the proviso).
(e) Thereafter the proceedings shall be governed by the
Uniform Rules of Court.
(f) The costs to date shall be costs in the cause.
(g) The applicant is directed to serve a copy of this
order on the respondents other than the second respondent and the
costs in
connection therewith shall be costs in the cause.'
2 The second respondent, the executors, are ordered to
pay the appellant's costs of appeal, including the costs of two
counsel.
______________________________________________________________
JUDGMENT
______________________________________________________________
CLOETE JA (SNYDERS, MHLANTLA, THERON and SERITI JJA
concurring):
[1] The parties have, sensibly, agreed that this matter
should be referred to trial. The only live issue in the appeal is who
should
pay the costs in this court.
[2] The second respondent, the executors who have been
cited jointly, submit that these costs should be paid by the
appellant as,
we were informed, he had persisted in seeking final
relief on motion before the court a quo up until the fifth day of the
hearing
in that court; and in the alternative, the submission was
that the appropriate order should be that the costs of appeal should
be costs in the cause. To my mind, the decisive fact is that the
appellant had to come to this court to have the order of the court
a
quo set aside and that entitles him to the costs of appeal.
[3] The following order is made:
1 The order by the court a quo is set aside and the
following order substituted:
'(a) The matter is referred to trial.
(b) The notice of motion shall stand as a simple
summons.
(c) The applicant is ordered to deliver his declaration
within 21 days from the date of this order (provided that the days
between
16 December and 15 January, both inclusive, shall not be
counted as part of this period).
(d) The second respondent, the executors, are ordered to
deliver their plea within 21 days of the date of delivery of the
applicant's
declaration (subject to the same proviso contained in
(c), should the declaration be delivered before or during the period
specified
in the proviso).
(e) Thereafter the proceedings shall be governed by the
Uniform Rules of Court.
(f) The costs to date shall be costs in the cause.
(g) The applicant is directed to serve a copy of this
order on the respondents other than the second respondent and the
costs in
connection therewith shall be costs in the cause.'
2 The second respondent, the executors, are ordered to
pay the appellant's costs of appeal, including the costs of two
counsel

sections.facts: The appellant, Martin Rosenberg, appealed a decision of the North West High Court (Mmabatho) where a procedural order had been made. The appeal primarily concerned the allocation of costs incurred in the prior proceedings. The High Court had previously ordered certain procedural steps, and the appellant sought to have that order set aside and the matter referred to trial.
sections.issues: The sole issue in the appeal was the determination of which party should bear the costs of the appeal, specifically whether the appellant should be awarded costs or the second respondent (the executors) should bear them.
sections.principles: The court applied the principle that a party who successfully obtains a reversal of a lower court's order on appeal is ordinarily entitled to the costs of the appeal. Additionally, the court noted that costs may be awarded as costs in the cause when the matter proceeds to trial, and that the Uniform Rules of Court govern subsequent procedural steps.
sections.application: Applying the above principles, the court found that the appellant had to approach the Supreme Court of Appeal to have the High Court's order set aside, thereby entitling him to the costs of appeal. Consequently, the court set aside the High Court order, substituted new procedural orders, and ordered the second respondent (the executors) to pay the appellant's costs of appeal, including counsel fees.
sections.conclusion: The order by the High Court was set aside and replaced with a series of directions: the matter was referred to trial; the notice of motion was to stand as a simple summons; specific timeframes were set for the applicant's declaration and the second respondent's plea; the Uniform Rules of Court would govern the proceedings; costs to date were deemed costs in the cause; and the second respondent was ordered to pay the appellant's costs of appeal, including two counsel's fees.
